references: Dataset. The experiments utilize two datasets: the Yelp.com dataset (Vu et al., 2020) and the TripAdvisor dataset (Vu et al., 2020) and the TripAdvisor dataset (Li et al., 2013). The Yelp.com dataset features over 67,000 restaurant reviews across three English-speaking cities. The TripAdvisor dataset consists of 878,561 reviews from 4333 hotels crawled from TripAdvisor.com across 17 cities. The dataset is partitioned into training and testing sets. Since we deal with the problem of cold-start user recommendation, we split the dataset so that users in the test set do not have any reviews in the train set. Since we deal with the problem of cold-start user recommendation, we split the dataset so that users in the test set do not have any reviews in the train set. references:
The goal of candidates retrieval is not only to achieve a high ranking (precision) but also to retrieve as many correct candidates as possible (recall). This ensures that the re-ranking module has a comprehensive set of candidates to work with in its input.
Therefore, we evaluate the retrieval methods based on P@20 and R@20, which measure the precision and recall of the top 20 candidates, respectively. The results are presented in Table 2, where the column ”Improve” highlights the performance improvement of our best retrieval model, MPG, compared to the best conventional method.
Our findings reveal that both MF and MVAE outperform Jaccard similarity-based method. However, these methods face challenges because they are trained on user-item interactions rather than keywords, making it difficult to accurately capture the intentions of cold-start users as expressed through input keywords. In contrast, approaches leveraging keywords exhibit notable enhancements. CBR performs better than all the baselines method as it utilized keywords to compute user and item representations. The best performance is achieved using MPG, which harnesses the graph structure between keywords and items. MPG demonstrates consistent improvement across three cities, enhancing Recall@20 by at least 21.38% and Precision@20 by at least 4.75%.
Furthermore, we examine the role of TF-IRF in constructing edges (Equation 6) and pretrained BERT models for the keyword vectorization. As shown in Figure 4, MPG with TF-IRF and ”all-MiniLM-L6-v2” outperforms other configurations. It is noteworthy that in our framework, achieving high recall is crucial, as these candidates will be re-ranked in the next phase.

RQ1. Can LLMs re-rank candidates to improve the cold-start user recommendation task?
We investigate the capability of using LLMs to re-rank candidates in cold-start user recommendation. Table 3 shows the comparison between retrieval only (CBR and MPG) and the full KALM4REC framework (i.e., retrieval and re-ranking using LLM – Gemini Pro). The results show consistent improvements when using LLM-based candidates re-ranking for both CBR and MPG, for all the datasets regarding the evaluation metrics. Additionally, there is a significant improvement compared to sole retrieval modules, indicating the extensibility of our framework with alternative retrieval modules in the future.

We also examine the performance of KALM4REC with different LLMs. Table 4 compares the performance of various LLM models –Gemini, GPT-3.5, Mistral 8B, and Llama3 8B– across multiple cities in Yelp dataset using Precision at 1 (P@1), Recall at 1 (R@1), Precision at 3 (P@3), Recall at 3 (R@3), and NDCG at 3 (N@3). We use MPG as the retrieval method. The results demonstrate that all LLMs enhance the precision and recall of the top recommended item.
Across all cities, Gemini consistently achieves the highest scores in almost every metric, demonstrating its robustness in identifying and ranking relevant item candidates. For instance, Gemini attains the highest P@1 values, indicating superior accuracy in recommending the top item. Additionally, Gemini’s strong performance in N@3 reflects its ability to rank relevant candidates effectively.
GPT-3.5 and Mistral 8B models also demonstrate improvements over MPG. Both models show competitive results in P@3 and R@3, indicating their effectiveness in providing multiple relevant recommendations. GPT-3.5, for example, often comes close to Gemini’s performance, particularly in N@3, suggesting its capability to enhance the ranking quality significantly compared to MPG. The Mistral 8B model, while not always leading, maintains consistent and reliable performance across all metrics.
Llama 3-8B, though slightly behind the other LLMs, still shows improvement over MPG in several metrics. While it may not be as effective in capturing the top preferences of users as the leading models, it provides a consistent alternative that surpasses the baseline.

RQ5. The impact of the number of keywords on the re-ranking performance.
Figure 8 presents heatmaps depicting the performance of KALM4REC across varying numbers of shots under different keyword conditions for users and items. The x-axis represents the number of keywords used to describe the user, while the y-axis represents the number of keywords used to describe the items. The color intensity reflects the model’s performance. The heatmaps reveal that increasing the number of shots generally enhances accuracy, fewer keywords can still yield relatively good performance. Besides, performance variations are observed depending on the number of keywords for users and items.
We also acknowledge that the quality of keywords can affect KALM4REC’s performance. To investigate this, we compared various keyword extractors in Table 5. Our experiments show that SpaCy consistently delivered the best performance in keyword extraction.
